The production of light olefins from the hydrogenation of CO2 is an efficient way to utilize CO2, where the surface oxygen vacancy in metal oxide plays an important role in CO2 adsorption and activation. Here, the Ga-Zr metal oxides were prepared by hydrolysis of urea at different temperatures and combined with SAPO-34 to prepare the bifunctional catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to light olefins. The surface oxygen vacancy content of Ga-Zr oxide increases with increasing urea hydrolysis temperature, and a high CO2 conversion of 26.4% and C2 =–C4 = hydrocarbon selectivity of 87.2% were obtained by a well-matched amount of desorbed CO2 and H2. Using the CO2 and H2/HCOOH/CH3OH as probe molecules, the in-situ DRIFT spectra reveal that the CO2 could be activated on surface oxygen vacancy and converted to CO3* and HCO3* species, which were further hydrogenated to HCOO* and CH3O* species. While the by-product CO mainly originates from the decomposition of HCOO* and the presence of SAPO-34 converts CH3O* to C2 =–C4 =. The current study illustrates that boosting the surface oxygen vacancy in defected surfaces of metal oxide and providing a matching H2 dissociation ability is the key to improve the performance of CO2 hydrogenation to light olefins. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 hydrogenation light olefins Ga-Zr metal oxide oxygen vacancy urea hydrolysis temperature Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Light olefins (ethylene, propylene and butylene) are the most important feedstocks in chemical production [1,2], being mainly produced by the steam cracking of petroleum and the dehydrogenation of alkanes [3]. Where, the production of these light olefins from hydrogenation of CO2 provides a green and meliorating pathway for realizing the resource utilization of CO2. Both routes of modified Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) and the oxide-zeolite (OX-ZEO) bifunctional catalyst can efficiently convert CO2 to light olefins [4]. Although the FTS catalyst exhibits high performance in converting syngas to olefins [5], the distribution of hydrocarbon products is always limited by the Anderson-Schulz-Flory (ASF) rule. While great efforts have been devoted to the development of OX-ZEO bifunctional catalysts, which provides extremely high olefins selectivity [6,7]. The OX-ZEO bifunctional catalyst, composed of metal oxide and zeolite in a one-pot system, mainly provides two active sites where the metal oxide species first adsorb and convert CO2 into oxygenated intermediates, and the zeolite subsequently convert those intermediates into light olefins [8-10]. However, low temperature is thermodynamically favorable for the synthesis of oxygenated intermediates from CO2 (200–300 °C) over metal oxide, and high temperature is favorable for methanol dehydration as well as CC coupling reaction (350–450 °C) on the acidic sites of zeolite [11]. Because of the unmatched reaction temperature, the rational design of OX-ZEO is required to achieve high catalytic performance, especially for the reaction of intermediate formation over metal oxide, which is the rate-determining step over OX-ZEO catalyst [12]. Surface oxygen vacancies are usually considered to be the active sites for CO/CO2 activation [13-15]. While H2 dissociation usually occurs at metal active sites, attention has been drawn to the wider exploration of Zn [16,17], In [18,19] and Ga-based metal oxides [20,21] in OX-ZEO catalyst for their key role in CO2 conversion to olefins. Our recent study also shows that the synergistic effect between Ga and Zr can promote the hydrogenation of CO2 to oxygenated intermediates such as methoxyl at high temperatures [22]. Since, the abundant oxygen vacancies in metal oxide surface have been usually reported to be exposed by adopting suitable preparation method or optimizing the preparation conditions [13,23,24]. Various modes of chemical reductant, electrochemical, hydrogen or active metal reduction, and different metal doping effects are usually adopted in regulating the abundant oxygen vacancies of metal oxides. Where, the simple and inexpensive self-precipitation synthesis method usinging the commonly used precipitants (NaOH, Na2CO3 and NH3·H2O), could enable the high concentration of surface oxygen vacancies in metal oxide [25]. However, the fast reaction rate can easily lead to local oversaturation and ultimately the formation of large and inhomogeneous particles. When urea is used as precipitant, the precipitant is first stirred and mixed well with the salt solution, and the urea is hydrolyzed at a certain temperature without a concentration gradient, thus achieving a more homogeneous diffusion of the active components [26]. The urea hydrolysis temperature controls the rate of released OH- and thus the rate of precipitation formation, which directly affects the crystal structure and physicochemical properties of Ga-Zr oxides [27]. For example, the CeO2-ZrO2 oxides prepared by the urea hydrolysis method show well controlled compositions at the nanoscale compared by the co-precipitation method [27]. In this work, the Ga-Zr metal oxides were prepared by urea hydrolysis method, urea solution combustion method and urea solid phase combustion method. Where the urea hydrolysis temperature was further optimized and the effects of temperature variations on the surface properties, crystallinity, oxygen vacancy content and H2/CO2 adsorption of Ga-Zr oxides were thoroughly investigated by various techniques. After physical mixing with SAPO-34, the synthesized OX-ZEO catalysts were applied for the hydrogenation of CO2 to light olefins. The structure-activity relationship inducing to the different reaction pathways for CO2 hydrogenation to light olefins was further investigated by the adsorption of HCOOH/CH3OH molecules from the in-situ DRIFT spectra. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Ga-Zr metal oxides were prepared by the precipitation method through urea hydrolysis. Briefly, Ga(NO3)3·9H2O, Zr(NO3)4·5H2O and urea with a Ga: Zr: urea ratio of 1:3:30 was dissolved in 70 mL deionized water and mixed for 15 min at room temperature, the mixture was then crystallized in a 100 mL PTFE-lined autoclave at a rotation of 30 rpm at the temperature of 70, 80, 95, 110, 125 and 140 °C for 48, 36, 8, 8, 8 and 8 h, respectively. The precipitate was then aged for 12 h at room temperature with stirring. The resulting suspension was centrifuged, washed, and then dried at 80 °C for 24 h followed by calcination in air at 450 °C for 4 h. The resulting Ga-Zr metal oxides were denoted as GZ-T. The sole Ga2O3 and sole ZrO2 were synthesized using the same preparation method at 95 °C for 8 h. As a reference, Ga-Zr metal oxides prepared under similar conditions at 80 °C with different urea hydrolysis time (24, 36, 48 and 60 h) were designated as GZ-80-t. For comparison, the Ga-Zr metal oxides were also prepared by the solution combustion (SC) and solid phase combustion (SPC) methods. For the preparation of the SC sample, the Ga(NO3)3·9H2O, Zr(NO3)4·5H2O and urea (molar ratio 1:3:12.5) were added to a beaker containing 55 mL of deionized water. The mixture was stirred continuously at 30 °C for 2 h, then dried at 65 °C to remove excess water, and the resulting gel was placed in a muffle furnace at 300 °C for 5 min and further calcined at 450 °C for 4 h. The resulting catalyst was labeled as GZ-SC. The procedure for preparing the SPC sample was the same as that for the SC sample, except that no water was added to the strating mixture. The resulting catalyst was noted as GZ-SPC. SAPO-34 zeolite was synthesized by the hydrothermal method [28]. A solution with a molar composition of 0.2 SiO2: 1.0 Al2O3: 1.2 P2O5: 2.0 TEAOH: 40 H2O was prepared using silica sol, isopropanolic aluminum, phosphoric acid and tetraethylammonium hydroxide (TEAOH). The mixture was crystallized in a PTFE-lined autoclave at 170 °C for 72 h, then the obtained solid was centrifuged, washed to neutrality, dried at 110 °C overnight and calcined at 550 °C for 6 h to obtain SAPO-34 with a Si/Al atomic ratio of 0.1. To prepare the bifunctional catalyst, the Ga-Zr oxide and SAPO-34 zeolite were ground in an agate mortar for 10 min at a 2:1 wt ratio. The solids were then pressed and sieved to give 20–40 mesh particles and 0.4 g was used in the reaction. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The samples were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), in-situ XRD, thermogravimetry and differential scanning calorimetry (TG-DSC), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES), N2 adsorption-desorption, electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), temperature programmed reduction of H2 (H2-TPR), temperature programmed desorption of CO2 or H2 (CO2-TPD, H2-TPD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (in-situ DRIFT). Further information on catalyst characterization is given in SI. 2.3 Catalytic activity test The activity of the bifunctional catalyst was evaluated in a fixed bed reactor. Prior to the reaction, 0.4 g of the bifunctional catalyst was loaded into a tubular reactor lined with quartz tubes (6 mm internal diameter). The catalyst was then reduced in H2/Ar=1:1 (20 mL·min−1) at 400 °C for 4 h. A gas mixture (CO2/H2/N2=24:72:4) was then introduced to carry out the reaction under the following conditions T = 390 °C, P = 3 MPa and gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 3000 mL·h–1·g–1. N2 was used as the internal standard gas to ensure accurate carbon equilibrium. Detailed calculations can be found in SI. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity evaluation The catalytic performance results of the bifunctional catalysts composed of Ga-Zr oxide and SAPO-34 are shown in Table S1. It could be illustrated that the GZ-SC and GZ-SPC samples exhibited similar CO2 conversion and light olefins hydrocarbon selectivity, while they are much lower than the GZ-UC sample prepared by the urea hydrolysis method, indicating that the combustion method may not be conducive to the dispersion of Ga and Zr species, which affects H2 dissociation and CO2 activation. The Ga-Zr oxides synthesized by the urea hydrolysis method at different temperatures were further studied and the results are shown in Fig. 1 & Table S2. It can be noticed that when the sole ZrO2 was combined with SAPO-34, the CO2 conversion and C2 =–C4 = selectivity were only 10.8% and 68.3%, respectively. While for the sole Ga2O3 combined with SAPO-34, the CO2 conversion reached 24.3% with a low C2 =–C4 = selectivity of only 56.7%. The reason for the low selectivity of olefins hydrocarbon of Ga2O3 sample is attributed to the strong dissociation ability of Ga2O3 for H2, resulting in the secondary hydrogenation of C2 =–C4 = to C2°–C4°. However, the catalytic performance was significantly improved for the samples that the Ga combined with Zr. Moreover, the CO2 conversion and C2 =–C4 = hydrocarbon selectivity increased from 12.0% to 24.7% and 58.6% to 88.7%, respectively, when the urea hydrolysis temperature was increased from 70 °C to 95 °C. As the urea hydrolysis temperature further increased, the CO2 conversion slightly increased while the C2 =–C4 = hydrocarbon selectivity slightly decreased. When the GHSV decreased from 3000 mL·h–1·g–1 to 2000 mL·h–1·g–1, the results Table S3 show that the gaps between each catalyst enlarged. Moreover, the GZ-140/SAPO-34 catalyst significantly outperforms the reported catalysts, as shown in Table S4. The catalytic stability of GZ-140/SAPO-34 catalyst in Fig. S1 illustrates that there was no obvious deactivation of the catalysts after 50 h of reaction, leading to a stable performance of CO2 conversion, C2 =–C4 = hydrocarbon selectivity and by-product CO selectivity around 26%, 87% and 59%, respectively. 3.2 Structure and morphology analysis The crystalline structures of the GZ-SC, GZ-SPC and GZ-UC oxides are shown in Fig. S2a. The combusted Ga-Zr oxides exhibited much higher crystallinity of ZrO2 than the urea hydrolyzed GZ-UC catalyst, probably due to the poor mixing of Ga and Zr in the combusted samples. The reason for the very weak diffraction peaks of GZ-UC is that the Ga and Zr were highly dispersed and may have formed solid solution of GaZrOx [22]. The TG curve of calcined GZ-SPC sample is shown in Fig. S2b. No weight loss was observed when the temperature was increased from 50 °C to 800 °C, indicating that the urea was completely removed during the calcination process. XRD patterns of Ga-Zr oxides are displayed in Fig. 2 a. The sole Ga2O3 oxide shows the characteristic diffraction peaks of α-Ga2O3 (PDF#06–0503) and sole ZrO2 shows the characteristic diffraction peaks of t-ZrO2 (PDF#50–1089) coexisting with m-ZrO2 (PDF#37–1484). While all diffraction peaks were broadened after the addition of Ga2O3 to ZrO2, the combination of Ga and Zr shows broadened diffraction peaks, indicating that the Ga-Zr oxides prepared by urea hydrolysis possesses large amount of amorphous structures. The absence of characteristic diffraction peaks of ZrO2 and Ga2O3 in the XRD pattern of GZ-70 oxide suggests that they are present in amorphous or highly dispersed forms. As the urea hydrolysis temperature increase, the weak characteristic diffraction peaks of α-Ga2O3 appear. While t-ZrO2 existed in the form of microcrystals when the urea hydrolysis temperature increased to 110 °C, leading to the gradual increase in the degree of crystallinity of t-ZrO2 along with the continuous increase in hydrolysis temperature. From the partial enlargement of the XRD of ZrO2, GZ-125 and GZ-140 catalysts, it can be found that the m-ZrO2 phase disappeared and the t-ZrO2 phase shifted to a higher angle in GZ-125 and GZ-140, which is attributed to the fact that the atomic radius of Zr4+ (0.82 Å) was larger than that of Ga3+ (0.40 Å) and the doping of Ga reduced the ZrO2 crystal spacing. However, the characteristic diffraction peaks of α-Ga2O3 still appeared, indicating that Ga was partially doped into the t-ZrO2 lattice, and a microcrystalline structure of GaZrO x coexisting with Ga2O3 was finally obtained. Meanwhile, the t-ZrO2 characteristic diffraction peaks of GZ-140 are more clearly shifted to the right, indicating that more Ga is doped into the ZrO2 lattice and more Ga-O-Zr structures are formed. Fig. S3 shows the XRD patterns of GZ-80-t metal oxides, and the diffraction peaks of α-Ga2O3 and t-ZrO2 are gradually enhanced with increasing precipitation time. TG-DSC curve of the precipitated GZ-95 before calcination is shown in Fig. S4a. The strong exothermic peak appearing at 329 °C could be related to the removal of hydroxyl group, the exothermic peak observed at 648 °C with no weight loss would be ascribed to the transformation of t-ZrO2 to m-ZrO2 [29]. The TG result indicates that the calcination temperature of 450 °C is high enough to obtain a stable Ga-Zr oxide. The structural evolution of GZ-95 oxide before calcination was investigated by in-situ XRD under air atmosphere at different temperatures. The results are shown in Fig. 2b. It can be seen that the Ga species were present in the form of GaOOH before 300 °C, while the peaks belonging to GaOOH disappeared with the rise of α-Ga2O3 peaks when the temperature increased to 350 °C. However, the diffraction peaks did not change when further increase the temperature to 450 °C, indicating the stable structure of GZ-95 oxide at 450 °C. After calcination, the structural evolution of GZ-95 oxide treated in 50% H2/N2 atmosphere under different temperatures was studied by in-situ XRD technique. The results in Fig. S4b show that the diffraction peaks of GZ-95 oxide exhibited no obvious change as the temperature increased, indicating that the structure of GZ-95 oxide was stable under H2 atmosphere. The representative TEM and HR-TEM images of Ga-Zr oxides are displayed in Fig. 3 and Fig. S5. Fig. 3a shows that the sole ZrO2 has an irregular shape, while the sole Ga2O3 in Fig. 3b exhibits the regular cylindrical structure. The GZ-95 and GZ-125 oxides in Fig. 3c–d also exhibit irregular shapes. Compared to GZ-95 and GZ-125 oxides, the TEM images in Fig. S5 show that the GZ-70 and GZ-80 oxides present a very similar morphology. Where, GZ-70 does not exhibit any obvious lattice planes, while GZ-80 and GZ-95 oxides exhibit the lattice plane of 0.275 nm, corresponding to α-Ga2O3(104). Moreover, GZ-125 shows the lattice planes of 0.268 nm and 0.291 nm, corresponding to α-Ga2O3 (104) and t-ZrO2 (012), respectively when the urea hydrolysis temperature is increased to 125 °C, agreed well with the XRD results. The particle size distribution in Fig. S5g shows that GZ-140 oxide exhibited uniform small particles with an average particle size of 5.24 nm, and the EDS mapping in Fig. S5h shows that the elements Zr, Ga and O are uniformly distributed in GZ-140 oxide. 3.3 Analysis of the textural properties The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of the metal oxides are displayed in Fig. 4 . All the oxides exhibit a type IV isotherm, indicating the presence of mesoporous structures. ZrO2, GZ-70, GZ-80, GZ-95 and GZ-110 samples show H2-type hysteresis loops in the relative pressure (P/P0) range of 0.4–0.7. The GZ-70 oxide has the smallest hysteresis loop, indicating a decrease in mesopore pore size. Ga2O3, GZ-125 and GZ-140 exhibit H3-type hysteresis loops, and the hysteresis loops of the Ga-Zr oxides move towards lower relative pressures compared to sole Ga2O3, indicating a slightly smaller mesopore size [30]. The pore size distribution curves show that all Ga-Zr oxides have a uniform pore size distribution with the average pore size ranging from 3.0 nm to 3.8 nm. The textural properties of sole Ga2O3, sole ZrO2 and Ga-Zr oxides synthesized at different urea hydrolysis temperatures are summarized in Table 1 . The Ga-Zr oxides exhibit a much larger specific surface area than the sole Ga2O3 or sole ZrO2, and the specific surface area of the Ga-Zr oxide shows a positive correlation with the urea hydrolysis temperature. Among the Ga-Zr metal oxides, GZ-70 has the lowest specific surface area and pore volume. As the urea hydrolysis temperature increased, the specific surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter of Ga-Zr all increased, since the high specific surface area of Ga-Zr oxides could provide more active sites and benefit the conversion of CO2 [31]. 3.4 Surface properties analysis The H2-TPR profiles of the metal oxides displayed in Fig. S6 show that the sole ZrO2, sole Ga2O3 and the Ga-Zr oxides all exhibit very weak reduction peaks. More specifically, when the temperature was lower than 400 °C, there is almost no reduction peak, illustrating that the reduction of Ga-Zr oxides is not easy at low temperature. The reduction peaks higher than 400 °C are attributed to the removal of lattice oxygen under the H2 atmosphere. The oxygen species on the surface of GZ-70, GZ-80, GZ-95, GZ-110, GZ-125 and GZ-140 catalysts could be illustrated by the O 1 s XPS spectra as shown in Fig. 5 a. After Gaussian peak fitting, all oxides were divided into three peaks: the peaks at binding energies of 529.5–530.5 eV are attributed to lattice oxygen (OL), the peaks at 530.5–531.5 eV correspond to oxygen defects caused by oxygen vacancies (OV) [32], and the peaks at 531.5–532.5 eV are attributed to surface adsorbed hydroxyl groups (OOH). The content of OV reflects the concentration of oxygen vacancies, and it can be seen from Table S5 that the content of oxygen vacancies on catalyst surface increased as the urea hydrolysis temperature increased, GZ-140 oxide exhibits the highest oxygen vacancies content of 30.4%. The result indicates that high urea hydrolysis temperature facilitates the formation of more surface oxygen vacancy, which is beneficial for CO2 absorption and activation [22]. Fig. 5b shows the EPR spectra of GZ-70, GZ-80, GZ-95 and GZ-140 oxides. The EPR signal at g = 2.0055 is due to the free electrons captured on the oxygen vacancies, where the signal intensity of GZ-70, GZ-80, GZ-95 and GZ-140 is gradually enhanced, indicating that more oxygen vacancies are generated, which is in good agreement with the XPS results. The atomic ratios of Zr and Ga elements in Ga-Zr oxides were analyzed by ICP-OES and the results are shown in Table S6. It can be seen that the actual Zr/Ga atomic ratios of GZ-70, GZ-80, GZ-95 and GZ-125 are close to the theoretical Zr/Ga atomic ratio of 3:1. However, the actual yield of GZ-125 and GZ-80-t (Table S7) are much lower than the theoretical yield, because the excess urea hydrolyzed and underwent deamination and condensation to form diurea. The metal cations chelated with the diurea and formed the complex, which decreased the yield of precipitate [33]. Therefore, a suitable hydrolysis environment of urea is crucial for the synthesis of Ga-Zr catalysts with high catalytic performance. The adsorption of CO2 and H2 on metal oxides has a great influence on the CO2 conversion as well as light olefins hydrocarbon selectivity. Fig. S7 shows the CO2 and H2 desorption profiles in GZ-95 in the temperature range of 50–800 °C; however, due to the difficulty in distinguishing between weak and strong adsorption, the CO2-TPD and H2-TPD profiles were further studied in the range of 200–400 °C and held at 400 °C for 40 min, where the profiles are shown in Fig. 6 and the results are summarized in Table S8. GZ-140 had the largest CO2 desorption peak area with a CO2 desorption amount of 190.8 μmol·g–1, while GZ-70 had the smallest CO2 desorption peak area with a CO2 desorption amount of 131.1 μmol·g–1. The H2-TPD profiles in Fig. 6b show that GZ-140 had the highest H2 desorption peak area. Apparently, the amount of desorbed H2 on Ga-Zr oxides increased in the following order: GZ-70 (440.2 μmol·g–1) < GZ-80 (460.1 μmol·g–1) < GZ-95 (475.6 μmol·g–1) < GZ-110 (481.3 μmol·g–1) < GZ-125 (490.1 μmol·g–1) < GZ-140 (492.4 μmol·g–1). The high amounts of desorbed CO2 and H2 of GZ-140 favor the conversion of CO2 [34]. 3.5 Reaction mechanism The in-situ DRIFT spectra of GZ-95 and GZ-70 oxides after H2 reduction are shown in Fig. S8a. The band at 3745 cm–1 belongs to the terminal hydroxyl group on the Ga-Zr oxides, and the infrared absorption band at 1988 cm–1 could be attributed to the Ga-H species [35]. It has been documented that the dissociation of H2 occurs mainly at the Ga-O site, which in turn generates Ga-H and OH groups [35]. It can be seen that the signals of Ga-H and OH groups in GZ-95 oxide are much larger than those of GZ-70 oxide, indicating that GZ-95 has a stronger ability to activate and dissociate H2. This is attributed to the higher specific surface area of GZ-95 oxide and higher Ga/Zr ratio (Table S9), which exposes more Ga-O sites on the catalyst surface to dissociate H2. Fig. S8b shows the DRIFT spectra of GZ-70 and GZ-95 catalysts treated in CO2+H2 flow for 30 min. Obviously, the intensity of the generated HCOO* and CH3O* bands on the surface of GZ-95 oxide is significantly higher than that of GZ-70, indicating that GZ-95 oxide is more favorable for CO2 activation. To further study the reaction intermediates generated from CO2 and H2 on the surface of Ga-Zr oxides, the in-situ DRIFT experiments were performed. After a pretreatment of CO2 gas flow, the H2 was introduced and the spectra were collected. Fig. 7 a and Fig. 7b show the infrared results for GZ-70 and GZ-95 adsorbed in CO2 flow at 280 °C and subsequently in H2 atmosphere. For CO2 exposure, the two characteristic peaks (1476 cm–1 and 1079 cm–1) are the asymmetric stretching vibration ν as(OCO) and symmetric stretching vibration ν s(OCO) of the surface-adsorbed carbonate (CO3*) species, respectively [36], and the band at 1636 cm–1 is related to the ν as(OCO) of the bicarbonate (HCO3*) species [37,38]. The band at 2967 cm–1 was attributed to a combination of CH planar deformation and COO– asymmetry stretching of formate (HCOO*) species [39] and the bands at 2885 cm–1, 1586 cm–1, 1381 cm–1 and 1366 cm–1 attributed to CH stretching, COO– asymmetry, CH planar deformation and COO– symmetry stretching vibrations of formate (HCOO*) species, respectively [37,40,41], which are due to the dissociated H2 in the pre-treatment. After switching to H2, the signals attributed to CO3* and HCO3* gradually weakened, while the IR bands attributed to HCOO* first increased and then weakened, and the bands attributed to methoxy (CH3O*) appeared at 2929 cm–1(ν as(CH3)), 2822 cm–1(ν s(CH3)) and 1149 cm–1 (ν(CO) of bridged (b–OCH3)) [39-41] and gradually increased with time. The presence of the same reaction intermediates on GZ-70 and GZ-95 catalysts indicates that the reaction pathways of CO2 and H2 are the same on both catalysts, and the difference in their activities is due to their different abilities to activate CO2 and H2, resulting in different intensities of the characteristic IR bands of the same reaction intermediates. The reaction pathway is that the CO3* and HCO3* species formed on GZ-70 and GZ-95 were first hydrogenated to HCOO* species, and the HCOO* species were further hydrogenated to CH3O* species. The CH3O* species appeared very quickly after the H2 purge, demonstrating that the conversion of CO2 to HCOO* occurs more readily than the conversion of HCOO* to CH3O*, and that the hydrogenation of HCOO* to CH3O* is more dependent on the activated dissociation of H2. To further confirm the reaction mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation on GZ-95 catalyst, the probe molecule HCOOH was brought to the metal oxide surface by N2 bubbles at 30 °C. Fig. 8 a shows the DRIFT spectra after the adsorption of HCOOH vapor at different temperatures for 60 min. The bands at 2941 cm–1, 1787 cm–1 and 1087 cm–1 are attributed to the CH stretching vibration (ν(CH)), the C = O stretching vibration (ν(C = O)) and the CH bending vibration (δ(CH)) of the gaseous HCOOH, respectively, and the bands at 1743 cm–1 and 1124 cm–1 are attributed to the C = O stretching vibration (ν(C = O)) and CO stretching vibration (ν(CO)) of the adsorbed HCOOH molecules, respectively [42,43]. The intensity of the characteristic peaks of the HCOO* species originating from HCOOH increased as the temperature rose. At 300 °C, the HCOOH bands almost disappeared, indicating the decomposition or desorption of HCOOH on the catalyst surface. The bands of gaseous CO (2167 cm–1 and 2111 cm–1) [44] were also observed [37], indicating that CO is produced from the decomposition of HCOO*. Fig. 8b shows that when HCOOH was saturated adsorbed on GZ-95 catalyst at 280 °C, the feedstock was switched from HCOOH to H2, and the intensity of the bands attributed to HCOO* at 1366 cm–1, 1381 cm–1, 1590 cm–1 and 2885 cm–1 gradually decreased and the CH3O* signal gradually increased with time, indicating that the HCOO* species could be further hydrogenated to form CH3O*. For the adsorption of CH3OH on the surface of GZ-95 (Fig. 9 a), the signals of terminal hydroxyls and multicoordinated hydroxyls at 3761 cm–1 and 3671 cm–1 gradually weakened, while the new bands appeared at 2822 cm–1 and 1145 cm–1, attributed to the ν(CH3) modes in CH3O*, respectively, indicating that methanol underwent the dissociative adsorption on the GZ-95 oxide surface and formed the CH3O* species: C H 3 OH + − OH → C H 3 O * + H 2 O [45]. The bands at 2870 cm–1 and 1615 cm–1 are attributed to HCOO* species. Moreover, Fig. 9b shows that the bands at 3750 cm–1 (Si-OH) and 3610 cm–1 (Si-(OH)-Al) decreased with time after the adsorption of CH3OH on GZ-95/SAPO-34 [46], while the bands at 2950 cm–1, 2923 cm–1, 2871 cm–1 and 2850 cm–1 attributed to the CH band of stretching vibration in *CH3 gradually increased. The bands at 1450 cm–1 and 1380 cm–1 are attributed to the CH bending vibration of aromatic species, while the band at 1610 cm–1 is attributed to the aromatic species generated during the reaction. As the adsorption time increased, new bands appeared at 3017 cm–1, 1510 cm–1, 1482 cm–1 and 1219 cm–1 (Fig. S9) are attributed to CH3 asymm stretch, allyl CCC asym stretch, allyl CCC symm stretch, and ip CH2/CH wag of the dimethylcyclopentene cationic substance (DMCP), respectively [47-49]. These results indicate that CH3OH can be rapidly absorbed at the hydroxyl site of SAPO-34 and decomposed to surface methyl and methylene species. The band at 2935 cm–1 is attributed to the v s(CH) mode of CH3OH [50], where the intensity of the bands of CH3OH on GZ-95 catalyst is significantly higher than that of GZ-95/SAPO-34, suggesting that the combination of zeolite with GZ-95 oxide significantly promotes the transformation of methanol. Based on the analysis of the catalytic reaction intermediates, a detailed reaction mechanism for the production of light olefins from CO2 and H2 over Ga-Zr/SAPO-34 bifunctional catalyst is presented in Fig. 10 . It can be illustrated that the CO2 was first adsorbed on the surface oxygen vacancies and then converted to CO3* and HCO3*, while the adsorbed H2 dissociated on the Ga2O3 surface to generate Ga-H and OH species, the CO3* and HCO3* species and the dissociated H2 from Ga2O3 reacted to form the HCOO* species, which were then sequentially hydrogenated to form H2COO* and H2COOH*. The CO bond of H2COOH* is then cleaved to form CH2O* [22], which is further hydrogenated to produce the CH3O* species. Finally, the CH3O* is rapidly converted to C2 =–C4 = in the pore of SAPO-34 zeolite. In addition, the by-product CO is formed from the hydrogenation of COOH* [22] and the decomposition of HCOO*. 3.6 Structure-activity relationship The relationship between catalytic activity, amount of desorbed CO2 and H2, and surface oxygen vacancy content is illustrated in Fig. 11 a. It can be seen that the amounts of desorbed H2 are much higher than those of CO2. As the surface oxygen vacancy content increased, the amounts of desorbed CO2 and desorbed H2 as well as the conversion of CO2 increased, indicating that the presence of surface oxygen vacancy facilitates the adsorption of CO2 and H2 as well as the conversion of CO2. Fig. 11b shows the relationship between the amount of desorbed H2 and the C2 =–C4 = hydrocarbon selectivity at the same CO2 conversion (12%). Obviously, the C2 =–C4 = hydrocarbon selectivity decreased as the amount of desorbed H2 increased at the same value of CO2 conversion, indicating that the high amounts of desorbed H2 resulted in secondary hydrogenation of generated light olefins which decreased the light olefins hydrocarbon selectivity. 4 Conclusions The Ga-Zr metal oxides were prepared by urea hydrolysis method, urea solution combustion method and urea solid phase combustion method, and the SAPO-34 zeolite was synthesized by the hydrothermal method. A physically mixed Ga-Zr oxide and SAPO-34 bifunctional catalyst was used for the hydrogenation of CO2 to light olefins. The results indicated various physical demonstration by manipulating the different temperatures in urea hydrolysis for Ga-Zr metal oxides. It was depicted that the Ga-Zr oxides exhibited an increase in specific surface area from 88 m2·g–1 to 141 m2·g–1 as the urea hydrolysis temperature increased from 70 °C to 140 °C. Meanwhile, the surface oxygen vacancy content increased from 19.6% to 30.2%, the amount of desorbed CO2 increased from 131.1 μmol·g–1 to 190.8 μmol·g–1, and the amount of desorbed H2 increased from 440.2 μmol·g–1 to 492.4 μmol·g–1, respectively. Where, the presence of surface oxygen vacancies facilitated the adsorption and conversion of CO2, where a high amount of desorbed H2 resulted in excessive hydrogenation of light olefins and the decreased the hydrocarbon selectivity of light olefins. The CO2 activated on Ov was converted to CO3* and HCO3* species, while the formed CO3* and HCO3* further hydrogenated to HCOO* and to CH3O* species, generating the by-product CO from the decomposition of formate. Moreover, the combination of GZ-95 and SAPO-34 led to a rapid conversion of CH3O* species to C2 =–C4 =, obtaining a high CO2 conversion of 26.4% and C2 =–C4 = hydrocarbon selectivity of 87.2% at 390 °C, 3 MPa, H2/CO2=3:1 and 3000 mL·h–1·g–1. In short, this work suggests that increasing the oxygen vacancy content while providing a matching H2 dissociation ability is the key to improve the performance of CO2 hydrogenation to light olefins. coredata.dc:description: The production of light olefins from the hydrogenation of CO2 is an efficient way to utilize CO2, where the surface oxygen vacancy in metal oxide plays an important role in CO2 adsorption and activation. Here, the Ga-Zr metal oxides were prepared by hydrolysis of urea at different temperatures and combined with SAPO-34 to prepare the bifunctional catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to light olefins. The surface oxygen vacancy content of Ga-Zr oxide increases with increasing urea hydrolysis temperature, and a high CO2 conversion of 26.4% and C2 =–C4 = hydrocarbon selectivity of 87.2% were obtained by a well-matched amount of desorbed CO2 and H2. Using the CO2 and H2/HCOOH/CH3OH as probe molecules, the in-situ DRIFT spectra reveal that the CO2 could be activated on surface oxygen vacancy and converted to CO3* and HCO3* species, which were further hydrogenated to HCOO* and CH3O* species. While the by-product CO mainly originates from the decomposition of HCOO* and the presence of SAPO-34 converts CH3O* to C2 =–C4 =. The current study illustrates that boosting the surface oxygen vacancy in defected surfaces of metal oxide and providing a matching H2 dissociation ability is the key to improve the performance of CO2 hydrogenation to light olefins.
